title: Kyle Sinckler on 'mission' to bring hope and glory home from Rugby World Cup
text:

Kyle Sinckler moved to within a win of the World Cup final but vowed not rest until he had provided hope as well as glory.

Brought up by a single mum on a south London housing estate, the young prop is acutely aware of the challenges facing the current generation of inner-city kids.

And after scoring the try which gave England a winning lead against Australia, then forcing the turnover that preserved it, he spoke movingly of his “mission” to be to them what England’s 2003 heroes had been to him.

“It’s a matter of having a responsibility to the grass roots,” he said, his gaze to the ground to avoid the acclaim swirling around him.

“A lot of people, when I was growing up, said I couldn’t do a lot of things, that I wouldn’t amount to anything. I need to show what is possible.

“I look at the stuff that’s happening around London with the knife crime. It’s just because kids are bored, sitting around. They want that adrenalin rush. They need to fall in love with some kind of sport, some kind of activity.”

Sinckler is clear a combination of rugby and “a good family” saved him from a world of bother. Others he knows are less fortunate. He wants to inspire them.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Where I’m from there’s a big onus on me to set a good example and show what being a man is,” he said after a performance notable for his refusal to react when Aussie hooker Tolu Latu tried to get a rise out him by patting him on the head.

“Being a man isn’t losing your rag, your emotions, showing your opposition how you really feel. A sign of toughness isn’t what you say or how you react with handbags.

“It’s your next action. It’s about being calm, disciplined, putting the team first, doing your job and not allowing your ego to take control.

(Image: Getty Images)

“You have to play on the edge and make sure you’re right there. But I’ve got a real big responsibility not only to the team, but the people watching back home. I want to leave a good example for them.”

Sinckler has worked his socks off to get to this point. He now admits that he lost his rag in this year’s Six Nations clash against Wales.

“I let the team down, I let my country down,” he said. “If we had won that game we would have been Grand Slam champions.”

(Image: Getty Images)

He traces his “frustrations” back to being “born in a single parent home and always looking for that male father figure”.

“Subconsciously, I put people in that position, put my trust in certain people who betrayed me really. It was just about me taking control of my life and teaching me how to be an actual man.

“A man is in control of his emotions, a man looks after his family, he does the right things. He doesn’t let anything that frustrates him show, he just gets on with it.”

Which is what Sinckler did against Australia. And with proud mum Donna in the stands it made for a grand occasion.
